ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: In addition to the lectures, the teaching assistants would also hold discussion sections where students could come in and ask questions about the problem set.

This class was a live virtual lecture that was also recorded. Outside of lecture, there were optional, virtual discussion sections that students could attend for help with the psets or reviewing concepts in class.

The organization of this course was a mixture of synchronous and asynchronous components which was fundamentally confusing. The lectures were recorded, except for the coding portions pf the lectures, which were then graded on attendance. When I enrolled, I thought it would be asynchronous, but then they introduced the participation component and did not record the coding portions of the lectures, which in my opinion was one of the more difficult parts. They also said that attendance at a synchronous discussion section was required each week but turns out they were optional. The mixture of synchronous and asynchronous components fundamentally confused the material and significantly hindered learning.
Also virtual section with TA's.
Live lectures were also recorded
Live discussion questions and student presentations during class
all class sessions were live virtual lectures

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the course title says it all
I learned how to code in Matlab and set up models for dynamic biological systems.

This course really made me think about the math behind a lot of biological processes that I already knew about. It was a great introductory course. It also teaches a bit of MATLAB, although it's definitely not extensive.

How to code in MATLAB, how to model biochemical interactions as well as gene expression and cell signaling networks. More specifically, we learned about biochemical concepts that allowed cells to make decisions and to have "memories" of those decisions (having ON/OFF states). For those who do not know much about biological modeling, we used mathematical equations to describe protein/network behavior. We then plotted those equations on MATLAB to analyze what would happen if parameters changed.
I learned a lot in terms of using MATLAB, as well as in using mathematics to model biological systems.
Basic matlab coding. Certain formulas and skills to analyze certain biological systems through gene expression, binding, and enzyme kinetics

I honestly think I got virtually nothing out of this course. If you really want to learn the material, I recommend taking Biological Physics (which I had taken prior to this class and covers the topics with much more depth) instead.
Basics of modeling biological system, especially gene expression and enzymes, using mathematical models
Applying differential equations and matlab to model biological phenomena such as enzyme kinetics and gene transcription.
I was able to acquaint myself with the programming language used in MATLAB and learn more about how to apply mathematical skills to biological questions.

You learn how to mathematically represent/model biological systems, what steady state and equilibrium mean, how to code in matlab, how to model dynamical systems (and perturbations), and about the processes that underlie differentiation and cancer pathogenesis.

I got a good understanding of how to model biological systems. I think this taught me three primary things: 1) how to think about modeling biology, 2) how to think about biology in simple/mathematical terms (necessary to model biology), and 3) how to work in MATLAB.
I was able to develop my math skills while also learn some Matlab coding.
I learned how to think about modeling and simulating biological systems.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the course is structured very well, and the content builds off each other. I only wish that we were able to focus a little bit more on how to use MatLab in the beginning of the course rather than having to do trial and error with the program on my own.

The instructors are pretty good and do a good job of explaining the concepts (although in reviewing the slide notes it's less clear). The TA's are great, and I think the balance of lecture, breakout sessions, and coding is very well balanced.

The course does a good job explaining ODEs (ordinary differential equations) and how to set them up. However, the structure of the class was a little confusing, and I would sometimes struggle to see how a certain topic would relate the foundations we learned in the beginning of the semester. Another weakness was with the instruction of Matlab. Since the class is focused on modeling biological systems, we barely learned how to code in Matlab, and often times what we did learn was limited to what we were expected to know for problem sets. I just wish the class provided a better foundation for Matlab so I would feel more prepared going into the homework assignments.

Strengths: Almost everything! I really enjoyed this class -- the problem sets were difficult but fair, TAs were helpful, the professors are great.

Weaknesses: The lectures felt a bit long sometimes. The professors tried to break them up with breakout room activities, but I think incorporating more would have been useful.

Strengths: The professors were great at explaining every topic in the course, and the exercises and problem sets really helped us in understanding the material. The papers that they chose for student presentations were all also very interesting and easy to grasp with the knowledge they gave us in class.

Weaknesses: Some of the questions on the problem sets were difficult to understand without the guidance of the TAs, and some MATLAB concepts were not taught prior to using them on the problem sets (e.g., structs). At the beginning of the semester, it was also not clear when we were allowed to use MATLAB to solve a problem. To improve, the professors could write out at the beginning of the problem set or in each problem whether or not we are expected to use MATLAB. It would also be helpful to have a MATLAB "cheat sheet" of the most important concepts in MATLAB for those who have never coded before. For example, what anonymous functions are and how to use them, or what an ode45 function is and how to use it. While these concepts were taught in section, some students could not make it to the discussion sections, and these sections were not recorded.

This was the worst course I have taken at Yale. It was horribly organized and caused me significant confusion despite having learned the material well once before in the Biological Physics course. Psets are assigned every other week, often covering material from multiple weeks ago. Then it would typically take an additional month to receive those graded assignments back, essentially creating a 6 week gap between learning the material and actually receiving feedback on it. On top of that, typically 6 weeks after the initial introduction of the material, we were on an entirely different topic/unit/professor and the feedback was virtually irrelevant to the current topics. Additionally, I have rarely seen the alternating professor lecturing paradigm work well for a course- and it certainly failed here. If you need to have 2 professors teach the material, at least limit transitions between professors- not KMJ/TE/KMJ. Additionally, the exercises every other week were just busy work graded on completion and virtually worthless to the material being learned. Not recording all components of the lecture further compounded the confusing and disorganized portions of the course. This was especially annoying because everybody enters the course with different backgrounds (especially in coding experience) and for fairness, the coding portion should have been lectured on and recorded so that everybody would get the same experience. The periodic presentations interrupted instruction further (as if there weren't enough distractions from the material already!). Readings were assigned but not tested on (until the final) which I think was useless. The lectures themselves were a mixture of text slides and written material which I didn't appreciate - please choose one medium or the other or at least don't intermix them throughout the entire lecture. In addition, the questions on the problem sets and final weren't always clearly stated and communication with some of the professors/TAs regarding questions was an issue. Don't bother emailing them with questions on the final- they won't respond. Not even 1 of the 4 of them. I truly hope that if they do teach this course again, they focus on coherency and consistency (weekly shorter problem sets are more useful than every other week problem sets which test on 2 weeks of material). Stop interrupting the material with breakout rooms that don't work (for any class I've been in). This course was HORRIBLY organized and suffered from a serious lack of consistency (2 alternating professors, biweekly psets not returned for 4 weeks, busy work grades (exercises and in class coding), 4 random presentation days, poor communication between professors and students about psets/exams, neither synchronous nor asynchronous lectures, break out rooms, etc.). If you read prior reviews, other students have also had these problems with the organization of the course- the issues aren't just due to COVID, so I hope they seriously consider restructuring it because this format doesn't work.
It was great! There wasn't per se a lot of independent material since a lot of it would build on top of each other. Also good MATLAB practice.

Strengths - the TAs were really helpful and the course content was relevant to those majoring in the sciences

Weaknesses - the problem sets were often very time consuming and the questions were often unclear or needed a lot of clarification from the TAs.
The course definitely goes very fast when it comes down to understanding the math behind a lot of the problems. There should definitely be some emphasis on helping students with this problem.

The professors are very kind and understanding. The TAs explain things in a very good way and promptly clarify questions about material and assignments. The content was interesting and not too much given the covid situation. The take-home final was nice for flexibility sake but too long.
Some lectures were not very engaging, which is likely due to the awkward nature of zoom participation. New workarounds gauging student understanding before, during, and after teaching concepts could be helpful.

I think this class is overall pretty good. I had a beginner's background in R and no background in MATLAB, but I found learning MATLAB pretty straightforward (although I imagine it would have been a bit tougher, but 100% doable, without any background whatsoever); they didn't teach much MATLAB in lectures, but they very much taught MATLAB in section, which I think was helpful for people who didn't have any background. The material was overall really interesting. I liked the format of the class (primarily lectures, with a few student presentations on current topics in quantitative biology) and the assignments (regular psets, take home final). 

I think the biggest weakness of the course in the logistical organization of it. This is not to say the lectures or the material was disorganized (I thought the lectures were generally pretty clear and fit very well together). But the psets were often posted late and/or had mistakes the professors had to correct, I thought the questions were often poorly worded/laid out (it was often not clear to anyone what the questions were asking, and the TA's often sent clarifying/explanatory emails), and class frequently ran very late (we'd start required MATLAB "hacking" literally as class ended, which meant you had to stay late to get credit). Again, I think the actual material was very clear and organized; the logistics of the class, however, could be improved.

This course was interesting and deviated from standard MCDB or MB&B courses. As an MCDB major, I had never taken a coding or engineering course at Yale. This class helped me think more critically about details that are generally glossed over in MCDB course (for instance, what does it mean for a signaling pathway to be turned on?). The instructors are wonderful, and class is engaging--frequently involving breakout rooms and small group discussions. I had no statistics experience, and was able to follow the course well, but I do think it would have been helpful to have a better background in statistics before taking the course. Additionally, I felt that the course was most clear when we related lessons back to physical biological systems. (the lambda phage class, oocyte discussion, glucose transporter) and sometimes the course became a little more difficult to follow when it became more abstract (discussions of oscillations, noise, or zero order ultrasensitivity). Perhaps tying those lessons more explicitly back to the physical systems would help make these lessons a bit more clear. Additionally, I was best able to follow the classes when there were reading assignments that directly paralleled class discussions. One of the weaknesses of this class is that there isnt a consistent textbook and reading assignments are often posted just a few hours before class, so often class was often the first time I had ever heard of a concept. It would have been useful to pick a few more reading assignments that followed class lessons. I understand there may not be one good textbook, but creating a course packet (as many humanities classes do) would be extremely helpful for students with less experience with the subject. Finally, the office hours for this course were a little bit inconvenient/limited. It would have been useful if Professor Miller-Jensen had office hours too!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that the exercises and breakout rooms were helpful for virtual engagement. A suggestion would be to screen share Matlab for some demonstrations on how to model things we've learned in class so that students get a better idea of what to do.

I think the breakout rooms were a solid concept and worked pretty well for most situations, but sometimes they were just silent and dead which is more on us as students than on the class architecture. Paper presentations were fun, OH was good. This was probably the lecture I had that adapted the best to the online format

The lectures were recorded, which made the class a lot more accessible and flexible. Zoom itself created a great opportunity for discussion sections since students who had troubles with Matlab could share their screen and have the teaching assistant comment on what the problem areas were in the student's code.

Breakout rooms to discuss course concepts were good, but the coding breakout rooms that got squeezed in with 5 minutes left ended with me staying  15 minutes late and missing the first few minutes of my section. I could have definitely left, but I needed the help with the code most of the time. It would have been useful to have those either during section or budget time better during class.

The professors integrated breakout room exercises into the lectures where students could discuss topics together. However, the professors would sometimes place two TAs into the same breakout room and have no professors or TAs in other breakout rooms, which meant that the discussion was not always verified until afterwards. For better engagement, it may help to note which people are placed into which rooms so that students have an equal access to faculty help.
Having the live lectures recorded was helpful in that I could go back and review concepts I didn't fully understand at first.
Breakout rooms helped to allow the opportunity to discuss things with peers and break up the pace from a 75 minute lecture.

Most students said that they appreciated the recording of the lectures prior to the course starting so that they could rewatch them anytime. They did not take advantage of this feature very well. Sure, they recorded most of the lectures, but they repeatedly interrupted them with breakout rooms and in class coding in groups - which consisted mainly of 1 person who knew what was going on because they had extensive coding experience and the rest of us just trying to follow, with little to no instruction from professors. They kept trying to artificially create an atmosphere of interaction during lectures which just did not work. Additionally, with the online format, it's possible to prerecord lectures so that they are as clear as possible, or record additional small lectures to supplement confusing material, but these professors didn't do that.
Virtual section was great. TA's are outstanding
The practice of recorded lectures was very helpful as it allowed students to go back whenever and make sure everything was understood.

The flexibility was very thoughtful and deliberate. I think that the final should have been shorter (it took me about 6-7 hours). I also think that the profs should try to develop new ways of engaging the class other than just asking questions since zoom participation is very awkward. Perhaps dedicating less time to teaching and more to in class coding exercise would have been better.

I think this class overall adapted well (live virtual lectures/section, with recordings posted), with the exception of the final. We were given three days during finals week to do the final (and were allowed to spend at much time as possible during that period). I was lucky that I did not have other finals to study for/take during this period, and I spent most of that three day period working on the final; I would have done a much worse job had I had less time to spend. I didn't think this was at all fair to students who might have had other finals to study for/take in this period. I think a fairer solution would have been to either 1) open the final for about a week, giving people flexibility as to when to sit down and spent a couple days on it, or 2) have it open for three hours during the normal in-class slot for this final.
live recorded lectures were excellent-- i felt this class worked well under the circumstances!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely recommend this course. Not only is MatLab a good skill to have, you get to have a better understanding of the formulas you've used in previous biology classes. Professor Emonet and Miller-Jensen are both super kind and explain the concepts very well (even in virtual format)

I would definitely recommend it if they are sure they're interested in the topic. I thought I was interested, but discovered over the course that it was not exactly what I had anticipated. This class is highly focused on developing simple mathematical models and simulations of protein and gene networks (for the most part), and while the logic and assumptions used to build these models are an interesting way of thinking and are well taught, I can't say I will ever be using any of this information since this is not the side of biology that I'm interested in.
That said, I still enjoyed the class, and appreciated that it taught a totally different side of bio than what I'm used to.

I would recommend this class only to those who have a strong background in math as well as biology research. Even though the class didn't require students to have research experience, I feel like those that did had a greater advantage over everyone else since they were able to better understand the research papers we discussed in class. Likewise, the class is very math-intensive and it can be very easy to get lost in the equations. This is especially difficult when the professors suddenly change the variables they're using in equations to match the work of other systems biologists.

Yes! Even if you don't have a math background, this class is very accessible to you. In fact, I would implore all bio majors to take the course to gain a better understanding of the math and coding that is so integral to present-day bio.

Yes, if you are looking to gain skills in biological modeling or MATLAB. It is super helpful in learning the general concepts behind mathematical modeling (e.g., how to simplify a mathematical equation to have less parameters, which includes nondimensionalizing equations) and how to evaluate common graphs in biological modeling (e.g., steady state analysis).
I would if the student enjoyed the mixture of mathematics and physics with molecular biology.

Absolutely not. This was one of the worst courses I have taken at Yale. Take Biological Physics instead. It teaches the same material (actually a bit more) but you come out of it with significantly greater understanding of the topics in part because this course is about as disorganized as possible.
Yes! Totally. If you like math and bio this class if for you.
If you are interesting in modeling and using a programming language to model biology, take the course. Otherwise if you are looking for an MCDB elective, take something else.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student only if they felt comfortable with their math background or else the course can be very challenging.

If you are interested in stable and dynamic biological systems, this is a cool class to take! Not too difficult, the professors and TAs are nice and understanding. With that being said, lectures can sometimes get dry and feel very long.
Yes! The professors are very kind and truly want students to learn.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student-- students came from very diverse academic backgrounds, and I think this course is a unique and interesting intersection for people of all different interests and experiences!
